Speaker: NA
Title: Unknown
text: i^ouse of Heprcsentatibcs.. Thursday, 18 August, 1904.. Mr SPEAKER took the chair at 2.30 p.m., and read praiyers. NEW ADMINISTRATION.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: Unknown
text: It will be remembered that the late Prime Minister made a statement at the last sitting of the House with reference to events which had occurred since the meeting of the House on Friday, and I now wish to state that, in view of the resignation tendered by the late Prime Minister of himself and his colleagues, I was commissioned by His Excellency the Governor General to undertake the formation of a new Administration, and that I have performed that task. Before naming the Ministers, and the offices which they will hold, I wish to make an explanation. It will be remembered that I invited the right honourable member for Balaclava to join with me, upon terms of ' perfect equality, in the construction of this new Government, and he has acted on that footing, and in that capacity with me, in the formation of the Government whose names I shall presently announce. My right honourable colleague, in view of the state of his health, still suffering as he is from the effects of a prolonged illness of a serious character, and in consideration of the duty which he owes to himself, has asked me to relieve him from any extra political work beyond that attaching to the Department with which he will be intrusted. As honourable members know, the position which he occupied under the arrangement made would entail a considerable amount of political work outside the particular duties of a Department, and in the present state of my right honourable colleague's health he-' would be absolutely unequal to any such task. Under these circumstances, he has asked my honourable friend, Mr Allan MCLean, to take the position to which I have referred in the Cabinet. I shall myself fill the office of Minister of State for External Affairs, and the list of my colleagues in the new Administration, with their respective offices, is as follows: The Hon. Allan MCLean-Minister of State for Trade and Customs; Senator Sir Josiah Henry Symon, KCMG., KC - Attorney General ; The Right. Hon. Sir George Turner, P.C., KCMG - Treasurer ; - The Hon. Dugald Thomson-Minister of State for Home Affairs; The Hon. James Whiteside MCCayMinister of State for Defence; The Hon. Sydney Smith-Postmaster General. These ' gentlemen will occupy the whole of the Departments allotted by the Constitution. I may add that the position of Vice-President of the Executive Council will be filled by Senator Drake.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: Unknown
text: Before the business of the House is proceeded with, I may perhaps be permitted, on behalf of the direct Opposition, to offer my congratulations to the new Prime Minister upon the names which he has submitted to the House as those of his colleagues. I am sure that, although we may differ from the new A d ministration in matters of policy, so far as personal considerations are affected we can extend to them the heartiest welcome .as Ministers in the new Government. suppose that all of us must acknowledge that, in regard to the probable administration of the Departments, there is not the slightest fault to be found ; but that, on the contrary, the best anticipations may be indulged in as to the.working of the Departments under the gentlemen whose names have been announced. On general matters of policy, I am afraid that we shall not be able to be quite so cordial.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: Unknown
text: G i v e them fair play

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: Unknown
text: S u c h expressions are capable of such differing interpretations that I. do not intend to indulge in them. I can only promise that the Government shall receive at ourhands such treatment as they merit in our view of the best interests of the country. I congratulate Ministers, and cordially welcome them upon their accession to office. ELECTORAL ACT COMMITTEE. Motion (by Mr GROOM ) agreed toThat the time for bringing up the report of the culated amongst honourable members. Select Committee on Electoral Act Administration be further extended to Friday, 30th September next. NA

Speaker: Mr MALONEY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I desire to ask the Minister of Home Affairs whether he will continue the work which is now bein^ carried out in connection with the addition to the electoral rolls of the names of persons who are entitled to be. registered, but whose names have been omitted owing to the hurried inquiries which were made wben the rolls were first compiled.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Perhaps the honourable member will allow me to answer that question in this way. I should rather, before any questions are answered, that Ministers should have some time allowed to them to consider the state of public business. MrM ALONEY - My reason for pressing the question at this stage is that if the necessary instructions are not issued to the police at once, hundreds of persons whose names have been left off the rolls, but who are justly entitled to be placed upon them, will lose their chance of voting.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I can promise the honourable member that the urgency of that matter will not be overlooked. ORDER OF BUSINESS. I Motion (by Mr Reid ) agreed toThat the consideration of all other business be postponed until after the consideration of Government business. SUPPLYBILL (No. 3). Mr SPEAKER reported the receipt of a message from H is Excellency the Governor General, recommending that an appropriation be made from the Consolidated Revenue for the purposes of this Bill . In Committee of-Supply: Sir GEORGETURNER (B a l a c l a v a Treasurer) - I move That a sum not exceeding ,£326,422 be granted to His Majesty for or towards defraying the services of the year ending the 30th June, 1905. The passing of this Bill is necessary to enable the Treasurer to provide the funds required to make certain payments which will f all due towards the end of the present month. The measure was prepared under the supervision of the ex-Treasurer, and I understand that copies of it have been cirI. have had an opportunity to go through it with the responsible officers of the Treasury, and I find that it makes provision for ordinary expenditure upon the basis of the last financial year. In the Defence ROLLS. Department one or - two large sums are proposed which I have ascertained are for the purpose of defraying the cost of certain ammunition-som e of which has been delivered-and for a portion of which we must pay when ordering. A further expenditure is required to provide the necessary prizes at some of the Rifle Association meetings, which will take place very shortly. The other items are not of a contentious character. Under these circumstances, I trust that honourable members will allow the Bill to pass as quickly as possible. . Mr WATSON (Bland) - I raise no objection to the passing of this Bill . As has been stated by the Treasurer, the measure was prepared at my instance, because, irrespective of a new Government coming into office, it would have been necessary to obtain Supply. Yesterday I carefully scrutinized its details, and in my view it is essential that the items outside of the ordinary salary votes for August should be passed at the earliest opportunity, with a view to maintaining the efficiency of the Departments.

Speaker: Mr CROUCH
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: When the Treasurer previously filled his present office, a promise was made that a refund should be granted of certain money which was paid by way of duty upon trophies. that the ex-Treasurer also assented to that course. As an urgent necessity exists for closing the accounts in connection with the recent fire brigade demonstration, I wish to ask the Treasurer whether he will make provision in the next Supply Bill for the refund in question?

Speaker: Sir GEORGETURNER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The amounts must appear upon the Estimates, and be voted in the ordinary way. They do not constitute ordinary expenditure.

Speaker: Mr CROUCH
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Some special items are contained in this Bill .

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: No ; except so far as the purchase of ammunition is concerned. Sir JOHN FORREST (Swan) - I wish to call the attention of the Treasurer to a public work of a very urgent character, for which the Parliament provided £ 1 2 , 0 0 0 last year, namely, ,£7,000 for construction and £ 5 , 0 0 0 for armament, although nothing has been done up to the present tim& I refer to the defence works at Fremantle.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: What became of the money which was voted?

Speaker: Sir JOHNFORREST
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I shall deal with that matter presently. an arrangement was made with the Government of Western Australia under which that State agreed to provide the necessary land for the purpose of the fort at Arthur's Head, and to regard it as transferred property. The public buildings standing upon the land were demolished, and everything was in readiness to give effect to the wishes of Parliament by proceeding with the erection of the fort. Difficulties, however, arose. The present Treasurer was of the opinion that the work, when finally completed, would involve an expenditure considerably in excess of that which was understood by Parliament when the £ 1 2 , 0 0 0 was voted, and therefore he urged me to refrain from expending ,£7,000 of the amount. He thought that we had not taken Parliament sufficiently into our confidence, and eventually the course which he suggested was adopted by the Government. He, however, undertook to lay the whole matter before Parliament, and to provide a sufficient sum for the current year's expenditure. He also promised to recommend that the necessary financial provision should be made for carrying out to completion the work in its entirety. Last year Parliament voted £ 5 , 0 0 0 to provide one gun for that fort. I regret to say that this amount was practically used by my honourable friend the then Minister for DeI believe fence, without my knowledge, but that fact will in no way militate against the progress and completion of the work. I rise chiefly to remind the Treasurer of the understanding which was arrived at by the Government of which we were both members, and to express the hope that on the Estimates-inChief he will give effect to that understanding, which I at the time communicated to the people of Western Australia.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I should like to emphasize the remarks made by the right honourable member for Swan, and to remind him that this is not the first occasion on which this matter has been mentioned in the House. It is only due to the late Government that I should mention that, on my representation, they agreed to provide on the Estimates for 1904-5 a sufficient sum to carry out these defence works, and that I informed the people of Fremantle that this course was to be pursued. I am glad that the right honourable member has confessed that it was with his consent that the money voted by the House for the carrying out of these works was not spent as proposed. Some time ago Sir JOHN FORREST - I did not say that. It went very much against my grain to see the money devoted to another purpose.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The right honourable member said that he was approached by the Treasurer of the, Government of which he was a member, and that he agreed to the £ 1 2 , 0 0 0 voted for certain defence works being devoted to another purpose, while the sum of £ 5 , 0 0 0 , voted for a gun, was commandeered without his knowledge by the honourable member for Eden-Monaro when holding office as Minister of Defence. I did not have the honour of being a member of the last Parliament, so that I am not familiar with the course of actdon which it adopted; but I was somewhat astonished to find that the House had permitted a vote passed for a specific purpose to be devoted to another object. The Disappointment felt by the people of Fremantle because of the failure to carry out these defence works was very keen. This is, I take it, a reasonable opportunity for meto express my disappointment that in the newlyformed Administration, Western Australia has not a direct representative. I do not intend to refer .at any great length to the personnel of the Government which meets the House for the first time today, or to any act that they may or may not have committed; but it is only fair to point out that the reason given by die Prime Minister for the non-inclusion of a representative of Western Australia in his Cabinet is that honourable members from that State are not to his political liking.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: If the honourable member will allow me to say

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Does the right honourable gentleman rise to a point of order?

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I wish to say, if my honourable friend will allow me. that it is not a fact that I gave the reason mentioned by him. That is all. I suppose any one has a right

Speaker: The CHAIRMAN
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Order . The honourable member for Fremantle will proceed.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I am quite sure that the Prime Minister does not wish to keep this side of the House as silent this week as it was last week. If he has any such desire there is no hope of its realization. I do not wish to criticise the present Administration, but I take this, the first opportunity, to express my deep regret thai: it does not comprise a representative of Western Australia, and to say that the reason which has been given in the press for the non-representation of that State in the Cabinet is one which ought not to be advanced by a statesman.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Hear , hear.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I shall reserve what I have to say on this subject for some future occasion. I hope that the matter brought forward by the right honourable member for Swan will receive the earnest attention of the Government, and that a sufficient sum will be provided on the Estimates to enable the work to be completed.

Speaker: Sir GEORGETURNER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I may say that I have some recollection of the matter mentioned by the honourable and learned member for Cc-rio; but that the item, which relates to a refund of duty on trophies, is one for which provision could not be made in a Supply Bill . Such a Bill is passed by the House on the assurance of the Treasurer that it provides for ordinary expenditure and a refund of Customs duties would not. come within that definition. I understand, however, that the Estimates will provide for a refund of the duty in question. Coming to the matter mentioned by the right honourable member for Swan, I think it will be admitted by all who have given the question any consideration that it is absolutely necessary that a certain sum shall be spent on works necessary for the proper defence of Fremantle and North Fremantle. 'At my request last session honourable members passed a certain item relating to these works, which appeared on the Estimates, together with a footnote that a further sum would be required in order to permit of their completion. That footnote was Inserted as the result of information afforded me by the Defence Department, in response to my inquiries; but when I subsequently discussed the matter with the Minister of Defence and Major General Hutton I found that a far larger sum- a sum of from £ 6 0 , 0 0 0 or £ 8 0 , 0 0 0 - woul d be necessary to enable the. work to be effectively carried out. Honourable members know that it is useless to only partially carry out an undertaking of this kind, and that we must be prepared to vote such a sum as will permit of the construction of the complete work, . so that it may be, not a sham, but a sure defence. In these circumstances I felt that I was not justified in committing Parliament to .the larger expenditure, and would not proceed with the work until I had had an opportunity to put the full facts before honourable members, leaving them to decide whether an expenditure larger than I had in the first instance anticipated should be incurred.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The larger sum is required in connection with the works at North Fremantle.

Speaker: Sir GEORGE TURNER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Provisio n will be made, not on the ordinary, but on the Special Works Estimates, for a considerable sum in relation to this particular work. Certain negotiations which have taken place between the Commonwealth and the Western Australian Governments have cleared the ground to a considerable extentThe State Government have agreed to treat certain lands, in respect of which they formerly asked a large sum, as being part of the property of the transferred Department, and in that way the actual cash outlay which otherwise would have been incurred in connection with these defence works, has been considerably reduced. I can assure honourable members that the right honourable member for Swan was in no way to blame for what occurred. He desired that the work should proceed, but I have always held that a Treasurer has no right to sanction a work which will involve a larger expenditure than was' anticipated until he has placed all the facts before Parliament, and enabled it to say whether the increased expenditure should be incurred. I repeat, however, that a considerable sum will be provided for in the next Special' Works Estimates. When those Estimates are brought down, the whole of the facts will be placed before honourable members, and it will be for the Committee of Supply to say whether the larger expenditure proposed is justified. After investigating the matter, as well as I was able to do, with the assistance of the responsible officer, I came to the conclusion that it was one which might well, be incurred. Question resolved in the affirmative. Resolution reported and adopted. Motion (by Mr Reid ) proposed - That IhetStanding Orders be suspended in order to enable all steps to be taken to obtain supply, and to pass a Supply Bill through all its stages without delay.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I , like the leader of the Opposition, must c o n gratulate the Prime Minister on the manner in which he has obtained office

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I would remind the honourable member that the question before the House is whether or not the Standing Orders shall be suspended, and that it is not competent for him, on this motion, to discuss the personnel of the Ministry or its policy.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: If necessary, Mr Speaker.. I shall conclude my remarks bymoving an amendment which will materiin a ally broaden the scope of debate, and enable me to discuss such matters. maintain that I shall be within my legitimate rights in advancing reasons in support posedof my contention that the Standing Orders should not be suspended on the ground that the Government have not the confidence of the House.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: To such a l in of e argument as that, I could not object; but I did not understand that the honourable member desired to take that course. On the question whether or not the Standing Orders should be suspended, any arguments which may be advanced in support of the honourable member's contention that the Government have not the confidence of the House might be in order.

Speaker: Mr BAMFORD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Clause 48.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I do not propose to deal with clause 48; it has nothing to do with this question. I am prepared to take the course I propose to take at the present stage, or to wait until a later stage when the Supply Bill is before honourable members, as on that Bill we can discuss anything we please. If you, sir, think that that would be a more opportune time, I have no desire to place you in an unenviable position, and I shall be prepared to take that course.

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: As I said just now, the honourable member would be in order in arguing the question whether the Standing Orders should be suspended or not, to incidentally refer to such reasons as he mentioned, but I think it would, be more convenient if the honourable member dealt with this matter on the Bill , when putting forward arguments why Supply should not be granted.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We can give the Government a fair show.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We intend to giv«; the Government every reasonable consideration. I am prepared to treat them just as they have treated us. They can ask for no more than that. I will defer the remarks I proposed to make until the Bill is introduced, in order that I may not in any wayhamper the procedure in connection with this particular motion.

Speaker: Mr BAMFORD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Giv e them time to ring up their supporters. Question resolved in the affirmative. ' Resolution of Ways and Means, covering resolution of Supply, adopted. Ordered That Sir George Turner do prepare and bring Bill to carry out the foregoing resolution. Dill presented by Sir GEORGETURNER , I and read a first time. Motion (by Sir GEORGETURNER ) proThat the Bill be now read a second time.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Probably this is a more convenient time to offer the few general remarks I propose to make.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I think the best time would be on the message to send the Bill to the Senate.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I have no doubt that the right honourable gentleman would.prefer that nothing should be said on the matter at all.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I wish to have the first word - that is all .

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: V e r y likely; and no doubt the right honourable gentleman would like to have a good many last words also. When the Labour Party took office under the honourable member for Bland, the Prime Minister rose in this chamber and told us that that honourable member had no right whateverto accept the responsibility of office, because he had not a majority behind him.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Who said that?

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The right honourable gentleman who now sits at the head of the present Government.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I thought it was the right honourable member for Swan.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The right honourable gentleman was not content with saying that in this Chamber, but he went whining about the country, telling people that inasmuch as he did not send for himself, instead of the leader of the Labour Party, when the Government, led by the honourable and learned member for Ballarat resigned, the action of the Governor General had been unconstitutional.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It has all come right in the end.

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The end is not yet.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: No w , what has been the action of the right honourable gentleman Despite his continual whine about his not having been sent for on that occasion, we find that he has accepted a similar commisAfter sion from the Governor General, knowing full well at the time that he had not jority behind him, and knowing also that he could not secure a majority except by humiliating himself and those honourable members whom he had to recommend to H i Excellency as responsible Ministers. The right honourable gentleman, when he came back from his interview with the GovernorNot General, was like a man who had secured a mining concession. He started to hawk it around where he could make most of it. He went first to the honourable learned member for Ballarat, and that orable and learned gentleman sent him to the right honourable member for Balaclava, by whom he was passed on to the honourable member for Gippsland.

Speaker: Mr CROUCH
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable and learned member for Ballarat would have notihing to do with the right honourable gentleman. Mr KING O'MALLEY - The honourable and learned member would not take any stock in the syndicate.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That was the position ; the honourable and learned member for Ballarat refused to have anything at all to do with the right honourable gentleman. He said, " No ; I have only made one political mistake in my life, and that was in joining a Coalition Government." The honourable and learned gentleman refused to have anything to do with the Prime Minister, but he passed him on to the right honourable member for Balaclava. We have then this humiliating spectacle in the present leader of the Government - The rigjht honourable gentleman went, cap in hand, to the present Treasurer, and said to him, " Although I am Prime Minister of this Commonwealth, I am only in that position nominally; I am not really Prime Minister, because you will have co-ordinate powers with myself."

Speaker: An HONOURABLE MEMBER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The right honourable gentleman sublet half of his contract.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: As the honourable member says, the right honourable gentleman sublet the formation of half of the Government'.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Sublettin g is illegal.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The Government propose to work on the butty-gang system.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I hope that we shall ? not find, in this instance, the amount of - sweating which usually takes place in connection with a contract which has been sublet. finding fault with the ex-Prime Minister, because he did not inform the Goa mavernor-General that he could not command a majority, surely it was the absolute duty of the right honourable member for East Sydney to give that assurance? But the s right honourable gentleman had a party of only four. H is whole party, all he could rake together, numbered no more than four. only was that so; but when he came to deal with the members of thei other party, they said, " We will join you, but you must swallow the whole and of your life-long principles." The right honhonorable gentleman had to swallow his on Life-long principles, and had to include in his Ministry men for whom he has the greatest contempt.

Speaker: Mr KING OMALLEY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Not contempt.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable member must know that I am not speaking in. a personal, but in a purely political, sense. I remember that some time ago the right honourable member for East Sydney delivered a very great oration, as we all know he can do, in the Melbourne Town H all , and on that occasion he referred to the Labour Partv as the " Steerage Party."

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is where the true gentlemen are-the true democrats

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I was present in the Town H all when the right honourable gentleman made those remarks, and I know that he did not intend them as a compliment to the Labour Party.

Speaker: Mr CROUCH
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The gentleman said lhat every protectionist was a coward.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The r e was another incident at that particular meeting of which I have a very vivid recollection.' member that the right honourable gentleman referred to the present leader of the Executive Council in another place, Senator Drake. The right honourable gentleman, in a sneering sort of way, said, " Now, there is that great and glorious statesman Mr Drake !" That remark brought rounds of applause. But now we find that this gentleman has been also swallowed by the right honourable member.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: There is lots of room !

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The right honourable gentleman came down to the House and, I think, on sixteen or seventeen occasionsI cannot give the exact number-tol d us that he intended to move a no-confidence motion. Every day the unfortunate reporters for the newspapers were waiting outside his door to ascertain just when he intended to move this motion.

Speaker: Mr HUTCHISON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable member did not believe it, did he?

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We were all deceived. The right honourable gentleman had other designs for getting upon the Treasury bench. First of all, he came to the conclusion that he must kill the Deakin Government. The method he adopted was that a number of his supporters should vote in a certain direction upon a certain clause, it being distinctly stated that if a certain proposal were carried it would kill the Bill .

Speaker: Mr HUMECOOK
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: They were wreckers.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: They were wreckers of the Bill , and at the same time desired to defeat the Deakin. Government. That Government was defeated. The right honourable gentleman pursued exactly the same course in connection with the late Government. He was not prepared to move a no-confidence motion. He was aware that if he submitted a straightforward honest proposal of that nature he would be defeated. He could not possibly have carried such a motion. Therefore, he endeavoured to attain his purpose by carrying an adverse vote upon a clause which was vital to the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill . I should not have spoken at this length, except that we know the right honourable gentleman and his methods, and we are aware that during the next three weeks he will be granting right honourable interviews and delivering addresses in different parts of the country. It is therefore necessary that we should as far as possible put our case before the public. The late Prime Minister is too modest on an occasion I re- like this. There is such courtesy in his disposition, .that he wishes to grant to the present Government a concession similar to that which he thinks was granted to him on a recent occasion.

Speaker: Mr THOMAS
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We will give the Government courtesy as soon as we have the numbers !

Speaker: Mr BATCHELOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We have the numbers today.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We have the numbers now, and the Prime Minister will either have to " stone-wall " this Bill , or he goes out.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I would not even encourage a debate upon a question of urgency.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The right 'honourable member cannot complain. I did not complain when he did not submit a straight out vote of no confidence in the late Government. Honourable members opposite were quite within their rights. They had a perfect right to adopt the method which they did adopt, if they thought fit. Personally, I should not have taken the course which' they adopted, because I thought it was a very questionable one; but technically speaking they were within their constitutional rights. But they must not blame us for taking a similar course when we think it expedient. It is just as well that we should face the situation. I am giving a start to a discussion which I trust will afterwards be carried on with more vigour and ability than I can command. When the Prime Minister had defeated the Deakin Government, he endeavoured to bring about a combination. Just here I feel that something ought to be said concerning the action of the honourable and learned member for Ballarat. The Prime Minister and the honourable and learned member to whom I have referred, came to a certain agreement. Of course, we have no right to object to their coming to an agreement, but what I did object to was that while the honourable and learned member for Ballarat had signed an agreement with the head of the present Government to form a coalition, he was at the same time negotiating with our party.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable learned member for Ballarat never signed an agreement for a coalition.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: He agreement to this effect-that the terms were to be submitted to his party. while he signed that, and was negotiating with the Free-trade Party, he was also negotiating with the Labour Party. That, to my mind, was a base act of treachery. Suppose, for a moment, that the Labour Party had agreed to the terms desired by the honourable and learned member for' Ballarat. What would have been the result ? Probably he would have gone to his party and recommended it to sell itself to the highest bidder.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: H as not the honourable member heard of a party in this Parliament which made such a proposal ?

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: No ; I have never heard of a party that did so. that the Labour Party has ever done, we are prepared to bring to the light of day. I am blaming the leader of the Deakin Government for the action which he took on that occasion. I maintain that to negotiate terms of agreement with the Labour Party, and also with the right honourable member at the head of the Government, was hot a fair deal. What came of it? When we hear from time to time statements made about the members of the Labour Party signing away their liberty because they have signed a piedge, I ask in what position are other honourable members? What was the position of the head of the Government, and the honourable and learned member for Ballarat when they entered into an agreement? They signed an agreement. Now we 'have a pledged party on the other side. Honourable members of that party, who, we were told, could always take each other's word, decided, on this particular occasion, tjhat they would have an agreement drawn up inblack and white, so that none might back down. ' I hope that for the future we shall not hear any more about the Labour Party being compelled to sign a pledge, seeing that the leaders of the party opposite cannot trust one another without a similar precaution. There is another little matter which I think ought to be mentioned, though only casually, because there will be ample opportunity later on to enlarge on these topics. I can remember when a Tariff was being passed by this House. The present Prime Minister then, in his place in Opposition, made such a pathetic appeal on behalf of and poor little children, whose boots were subject to a duty of 30 per cent., that the ladies in the gallerywere obliged to use their handsigned an kerchiefs ; indeed, the honourable gentleman's own tears dropped on his notes But as he spoke. At one moment he fairly wept, and the next he yelled, at the top of his voice, denunciations of what he termed the outrageous duties of 30 per cent, on hats and boots. But what do we find now? The honourable gentleman has swallowed the 30 per cent, on boots, and the 30 per cent, on hats, and what has become of the little children of whom he spoke does not matter, because he has now attained the ambition of his life-h e has become Prime Minister of Australia. However, as I say, there will be ample time later on to deal with these matters; but before I sit down I should like to ask the honourable member for Gippsland whether he feels nice and comfortable in his present position ? Anything That honourable member advocated the stock tax to its fullest extent, while the Prime Minister vigorously denounced that impost; but now we find those gentlemen arm in arm.

Speaker: Mr RONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: "Adversit y makes us acquainted with strange bed-fellows."

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is quite true. What does this Government, with its mixed elements, propose to do? The Prime Minister, and those who support him, once talked about the rule of the caucus; but what is their own position now ? They are so bound hand and foot that not one can move. Even the Prime Minister dare not take independent action, as a Prime Minister should, because he has to consult his co-equal in the Cabinet.

Speaker: Mr MAUGER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: H is equal in all things.

Speaker: Mr MCDONALD
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is .so. Talk about shackles! Why, the Prime Minister is chained up more than any man of whom I have yet heard of in political life. In what little experience I have had of politics I have never heard of a gentleman accepting the position of Prime Minister who allowed himself to be shackled as the leader of the present Government has on this occasion. T hope that the Commonwealth will never see a similar spectacle-that the Commonwealth will never see another gentleman so degrade his position as to be only half a Prime Minister. I shall not, however, pursue that line of comment; I see I am treacling on dangerous ground. I have had my little innings this afternoon, and olhers may follow me if they so desire. In any case, there is not the slightest doubt that at the end of three weeks, just before this Government are turned out. we shall have ample opportunity to let them know what we think. The Prime Minister cannot take exception to the course which I am following; the example has been set by himself. When the amendment was submitted, which resulted in the defeat of the late Government, the Prime Minister was told that the tactics to which he was then resorting might be used against himself; and I promise the honourable gentleman that, so long as I sit in the House, I shall fully avail myself of such tactics as are within my knowledge. The present Government and their supporters had. no doubt, a perfect right to displace the late Government, even by the questionable methods then adopted; and the Labour Party have no cause to feel discontented. .We are a growing party; indeed, we are the most powerful political party in Australia. There never has been a similar party in this country; and our great power is shown in the fact that the chief political leaders of Australia have had to swallow their life-long principles in order to obtain a momentary victory. The Labour Party could not have been beaten in any other way than that which the late Opposition followed. The power of our party is growing from day to day; and honourable members opposite, who see that it is ultimately going to rule the Commonwealth clutch at a straw in the hope of arresting our progress. I congratulate the Prime Minister on selecting, as his coequal, the honourable member for Gippsland- a gentleman whose fine democratic and advanced ideas are well known all over Australia, although it is a .fact that he always gives a Conservative vote. 7 H . now have the extreme protectionist in the person of the honourable member for Gippsland, and the extreme free-trader in the person of the Prime Minister, in the same Government- Those gentlemen might rightly be termed the " heavenly twins," though whether they will ever wear the heavenly wreaths is quite another matter. I regret that the Prime Minister has already had to announce a slight split in the Cabinet, he having had to accept another co equal in place of the gentleman he desired to have. In any case, I can assure him that he has my hearty congratulations on his attainment of the ] osition he now occupies; and I also can assure him that there are a large number of honourable members on this side who will give him encouragement and ample opportunity to deal with the business of the House.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I rise to congratulate the Prime Minister and his colleagues on the feat they have accomplished during the last few days. I am not going to complain- I have no right to complain-of the turn events have taken in regard to the Ministry of the Commonwealth. As a labourite, who belongs to the advancing army of democracy, I am delighted to find that at last, after only a few years of organizing and of political work, we have, by the aid of the arch Conservative of the Commonwealth, separated those who are with us from those who are against us. That fact is now indicated by the seats honourable members occupy in this House. The position of parties today, in this Parliament, is to me a pleasing feature in the political history of the Commonwealth. No one in the ranks of the Labour Party ever expected that the time would come so quickly when we should be able, without any doubt, to single out our opponents and mark them off for what they are. What is the obiect of this strange combination that we see? The honourable member for Kennedy has hinted at the object as though it was something which was unwelcome to the people of Australia. In the Cabinet I see elements which, before the Labour Partv became the factor that it is. fought bitterly one against the other, on the alleged sacred principles of protection or free-trade. But when they find, as they do today, that the Labour Party has been growing anace like the bav tree, and is spreading its branches over the democracv of We Australia, and welcoming converts from every side, what dp they do in order " down '' that party ? - They do what never been witnessed in the history of Legislature within the Empire. will .those persons who for years have mired the - standard-bearer of the glorious people for whom they are fighting. doctrines of free-trade and liberty say .he returns to Sydney, and they recognise that the banner under which they have shipped and fought has been changed, that it is not merely a question of "yes" today and " no " tomorrow, but is a quesmanufacture, tion of "Yes-no" perpetually? no" is a fitting conjunction of words describe this Cabinet. It is no longer a the question of altering opinions. before us a combination which is unadvancement. precedented in the political history of country. Of course the Labour Party are .highly delighted, because, whilst our right honourable friend on the opposite' side gines that he is going, as it were, to steal march on the army of democracy by singsome ling out those respected protectionists have long commanded the respect of their party, and believes that he will thereby bring behind the Cabinet the large mass the protectionist support, is it likely that will happen ? When he appeals to the country he will get the support of only the Conservaney tive section of the protectionists. democratic section of the party will never been created in Australia. stand behind a Conservative Cabinet such they see in this Chamber today. What the position ? A new line of demarcation has today been laid down in the political - history of the country. Hitherto the tectionists have been combined, and worked in unison, believing that the trine they preached was for the benefit all. But today we find that the people, reason of education on the fiscal quesfriends tion, are beginning to realise that there are ist; or free-traders. two sections in the Protectionist just as there are two sections in the Freemen, trade Party. The people are beginning realise that the Conservative protectionist the man who wants protection so that he can favour the manufacturer all the time, so that monopolies may grow and overshadow themselves-fo the rights, the liberties, and the very living of the people. The people are betive ginning to realise that there are Conservato tive protectionists who are prepared work for monopolies every day they sit on the benches here, every day they speak in support of their ciples. The Democratic comprise the men who have sympathy with the toiling men and women in our factories, Mr We.bste*. to who wish to make the lives of these people has brighter than they have been. This secany tion of the protectionists are going to tear What themselves asunder from the old monopoadlistic protectionists, and stand by the The when Liberal protectionist who today stands by the people in the interests of that fiscal worfaith, as it might be called, says, " We and want to make work in this country; we want protection, not merely for articles of but also for the lives and the "Yesfreedom of the workers in those industries. to We desire that the conditions under which people work in protected inWe have dustries shall be such as to tend to their We desire that these people this shall be allowed to work under conditions which will improve their constitutions, and make them better members of society. We imadesire that they shall work for only so a many hours a day, so that they may have time for recreation and education. who We desire also that the people who work in protected industries shall have preserved to them the right to obtain a livof ing wage for their labour." That is the that position of the Liberal protectionist today. The right honourable member for East Sydis. welcome to his allies. He has selected The the most Conservative Cabinet which has ever If he had as questioned every man in the Chamber he is could not have succeeded in constructing a more Conservative Cabinet that he leads todav, and I congratulate him on his work. proIt is a distinct step in advance for the have labour movement. We know exactly who docare our foes, and what we have to meet. of Hitherto we have been deceived, to some exby tent, by men who have professed to be the of the people, whether as protectionWe have been deParty, ceived by the platform utterances of these when they have been appealing to the to proletariat to give them place and power. is They will no longer be able to throw dust in the eyes of the toilers, because the men who are fighting for the toilers have severed r ever, I hope-fro m gentlemen who are prepared to support a protecpolicy only so long as it gives a monopolv the capitalist and a greater pull out of to the Customs duties which the Parliament has imposed. I do not intend to deal unfairly with the Government, although they prinhave not shown to me or to the party I beprotectionists long to that fairness which we might have expected to receive. I recognise that two - wrongs do no't make a right. I do not intend to mete out the same treatment to those honourable members who would not allow me to speak the other day, who kept me within .the four corners of the strictest rules of debate, who were always raising points of order, and making interjections irrelevant and otherwise. As I said during that debate, I would not support nv party in taking a mean advantage of any other party, but whenever war is proclaimed, and the field is cleared for action, I stand in the front ranks, or, if necessary, behind as a powder monkey, to assist to 'force the battle to an honourable conclusion, to the end that the best side may win. We expect to meet those honourable gentlementhose free-traders, those protectionists, those " pro-traders " and " freetectionists " whom we can now define, so far as Socialism is concerned, who have sunk their principles and combined for the sole purpose of securing place and power. I tell the right honourable member for East Sydney, without fear or hesitation, that never before, in Australia, did a leader display such anxiety to attain the ambition of his life, show such eagerness when he thought that it was within his grasp, or so abuse the ordinarymethods of fair play. I could forgive the honourable and learned gentleman for the methods he has used, but how can any one forgive a man who has sacrificed those life-long principles which have kept him in politics for so many years ? I. have heard the right honourable gentleman declare in the Town H all at Sydney, and in other parts of the Commonwealth, that free-trade is the doctrine for which he has the highest admiration. We all know his characteristic style. If he cannot influence an audience by his logic or his rhetoric, he will gain their support by his humour. But notwithstanding his versatility, I am sure that New South Wales free-traders and Victorian protectionists alike must feel that they have been deceived. left free-trade at the mercy of the protectionists, and is being supported today by men whose arch enemy he was a year or two ago. I keenly sympathize with the democratic free-traders who stand behind this conservative combination: I know how they are hobbled and haltered. The Prime Minister complimented them in the press the other morning for their loyalty to him. He said, "They never questioned me. They followed me whether I did right 01 wrong. Even when I took an unmanly attitude in regard to the Labour Government I was able to tell them to sit down, and they sat down." Even the most robust member of the right honourable gentleman's party, the honourable and learned member for Werriwa, a nitherto untamable character, whom the Prime Minister was never before able to bring under his hypnotic eye, was compelled to be silent on that occasion. When that debate was in progress, I said that it was unfair to tie the hands of the Labour Party, and that it was also unfair to tie the hands of the democratic section of the free-trade party. But what does unfairness matter to a man who is eager for office. There are democrats behind the right honourable gentleman, who for years have fought for democracy; but they have succumbed to his hypnotic influence in a manner which I did not think possible. We look to them to help us to carry out the great work of liberal reform; but today they are bound and helpless, and unable to say a word in defence of their position. We know how uncomfortable they must feel, because they are Radicals at heart, and represent constituencies of working men, who know what they want. Yet these unfortunate members have to support the most conservative Ministry that has yet been hatched in Australian politics. Why did not the Prime Minister exercise some charity towards them? Why did he not allow them to say a word in defence'of their position? Why did he not allow them to act as free men, instead' of gagging them, and binding them hand and feet ? The Labour Government were put out on a technicality, and by methods repugnant to British instincts of fair play. The followers of the present Prime Minister were not allowed to exercise the right of free speech, and to criticise the policy or administration of the late Government. All that we heard on this side of the Chamber, hour after hour, was " Clause He has 48." If the present Government receive similar treatment, they will have no ground for" complaint. My political existence has been threatened by those who have humiliated so many of my old colleagues; but I am ready to go down fighting for the cause which I have supported so long. I would rather die than haul down my flag, as some men have done. It is a degrading thing that a man who has received the Cobden Medal, and who has spoken for years on the advantages of free-trade, should now combine with men who have supported a oolicy which he has referred to as industrial strangulation. What a blot upon Australian history it is that there should be such a combination brought about, not to secure the administration of the affairs of the Commonwealth on constitutional lines-becaus e there is nothing but praise to be given to the late Government for the manner in which they administered the affairs of State-and not because the legislation put forward by the late Government was antagonistic to the views of a majority; but to secure merely personal ends. The members of the" Labour Party were forced out of their position on the cross benches to take control of the Departments of the Commonwealth, but the nine or ten free-traders who helped to put them in that position have since gone back on their principles, in order to give office to the right honourable member for East Sydney, who has desired it so eagerly and so long. These honourable members, although they condemned the Bill in to to, acting under the hypnotic influence of the Prime Minister, walked over to the other side of the House, in order to give him the opportunity for which he was longing. The Deakin Government went out ostensibly on a matter of principle, and the Labour Party came into power, not at their own desire, but simply because the trap set by the Prime Minister did not serve his purpose. Now, the very men whose votes contributed to place the Labour Government in office have assisted to confer power upon the deadly enemies of democratic legislation. The Prime Minster says that he will take up the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill . He will embrace that measure in the same way that he has embraced the honourable and learned member for Ballarat. The right honourable gentleman is capable of embracing anything. such a generous political godfather that he is prepared to adopt anything that comes his way, provided that he can retain power. This has been characteristic of the right honourable gentleman throughout his political career. Many of us are well aware of this, but other honourable members, who have not taken the trouble to inquire closely into his political history, will have cause for regret before very long. Does the right honourable gentleman suppose that when we reach clause 48 of the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill we shall be content to allow it to retain its present form?

Speaker: Mr SPEAKER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honoi Me member must not anticipate the de-bate on the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill .

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I thought that this motion was broad enough to cover every subject under the sun. If it is not, we shall deal with the Arbitration Bill at another time - No one desires more than I do to observe the rules of the House, and if I transgress it will be because we are all human, and liable to err. . Mr SPENCE - What does the honourable member propose to call the present Government? Is it a Socialistic Ministry-o r what ?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I should call it the arch-conservative combination of the British Empire.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: E very combination ought to be conservative.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is, no doubt, a sound proposition. The right honourable gentleman can prepare the way for himself better than any man I know. No matter on which side of the fence he finds himself, he can always give reasons why he should not be on the other side. Many honourable members on the Government benches are very uncomfortable because they are not in their proper positions. I sympathize with them in the same way that I should sympathize with the bird caught in the snare of the fowler. I believe that the time is not far distant when they will realise exactly where they stand. We are not troubled about being relegated to this side of the House. This is the first chance that we have had, as a party, to fight as members of a direct Opposition. The Prime Minister has never before had the Labour Party in direct opposition to him. He should be glad of the opportunity which is now presented to put them to the He is test in that capacity. Whether his pleasure will be lasting is quite another matter. From today it should go forth to the public that the fiscal question has no longer any political existence within the Commonwealth.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: t thought' that the Labour Party was a free-trade-protectionist combination.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I have nothing to do with what the right honourable member thinks, but I am dealing with the facts presented to us. I sympathize deeply with the deluded free-traders of New South Wales-wit h those men who have stood by the free-trade flag, and have honestly and sincerely battled for the policy which, in their opinion, would give freedom to the people, and enable them to overcome the difficulties of life with greater success than would be possible under other condiand tions. These men have travelled miles and miles to hear the Prime Minister, and which have worn their boots out in working the return of his supporters. they saying today ? I have been in South Wales for only 48 hours since our meeting on Friday last, and the impresparatively sion I derived from the demeanour of the free-traders there was that a double ral was taking place in that State. In course of my travels I met some of the strongest supporters of the Free-trade policy, and they said, " What do you think about it? Could you have believed that the Free-trade Party would be sold as they have been ? We worked for years to port the free-trade doctrine, and longed an opportunity to subject it to a practical test; but alas ! alas ! the man in whom placed our trust, the idol whom we have worshipped so long, has broken asunder, and has been practically absorbed by the mercial supremacy from her handsparty of which he was the avowed enemy for so many years."

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Did they say that I was we shall know it very shortly. broken asunder ?

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: No ; they said that the right honourable gentleman was burst asunder. Ambition bursts many men. That tragic consequence has been visited upon some of the greatest men who ever be lived, and, politically speaking, ambition has burst the right honourable gentleman. The I sympathize, also, with the people of toria, who have in the past pinned their faith to the champions of Protection. The honourable and learned member for Ballalonger rat who played such a prominent part bringing about the coalition, occupies position which, so far as the fiscal question is concerned, is inexplicable to me. When I first came into this House, I listened with admiration to the eloquence of the honourable and learned member, and I felt that if ever there was a sincere man he was one. Now, however, that I have an opportunity of contrasting the actions of the honourable member with his maglong nificent oratorical flights, and his - uices in connection with the Conciliation and Arbitration Bill , that he did not wish to alter the Bill , except sd far as might necessary to make it read correctly, I am decav. amazed. A few months after I was so favourably impressed by the honourable and learned member I see him sitting side by side with the enemies of democracy, acting as a buffer between the free-trade protectionist parties, and endeavouring to soften the effects of the collision must sooner or later come. for Why ? Because he hopes that his opporWhat are tunity will come some other day. Does New he stand aloof from the present Ministry because he anticipates that within a combrief period a little inspired message will come from the British Isles, funeurging the leader of the Government to the adopt a policy of preferential trade? Is it not possible that the Prime Minister, who has gone back upon his free-trade principles, will be found advocating such a policy ? I venture to say that he will prove quite equal to the occasion should it arise. supHe will declare that his duty to the Emfor pire upon which the sun never sets impels him to adopt a policy which will insure we to the mother country a certain amount of freedom from the competition of those nations which are fast wresting her comIf that be the secret of the split which, has taken place between the Conservative protectionists and the Liberal protectionists, At any rate, I cannot congratulate the honourable and learned member for Ballarat upon his action in practically strangling the Arbitration Bill . I appeal to the democracy of Australia, irrespective of whether they free-traders or protectionists, to be " up and doing," because our clay is coming. sun is up; it has not yet set. VicI urge the democracy of the Commonwealth to prepare for the political battle which is inevitable. The Liberal Party will be no sundered by rival fiscal creeds. Its in members will meet their opponents in a a fair hand-to-hand fight. I welcome that fight, and I rejoice at the prospect of affording the people of Australia an opportunity to combat their arch enemy. In my opinion, the life of this Government will be a brief one. Our turn must come, and it will last so long as we serve a majority of the electors, so long as we make Australia a better country than it is, and so as we continue to remove the shackles assurof those who. are oppressed. When our party resumes responsibility it will continue to hold office, whilst that which is led by be the Prime Minister will rapidly sink into

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: In view of the charges which were recently made by honourable members opposite to the effect that they were " gagged " -

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The gag moved.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: S in c e the supporters of the late Government crossed to the Opposition side of the chamber they have ungagged themselves - When they sat behind the VVatson Administration we heard no fiery invective from the honourable member for Gwydir.

Speaker: Mr WEBSTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I was " gagged " last week, otherwise the honourable member would have heard me to some purpose.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable member was not "gagged " by the Opposition.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Did we not hear the honourable member for Gwydir upon this day week ?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We did, and as far as I am aware, he could have continued to address the House until the present time.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: No ; the debate 'upon the motion which he submitted was interrupted at half-past 4 o'clock.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That marked only one stage of the proceedings. seems strange that this little rift in the lute is now being held up to scare the protectionists of Australia. An effort is being made to show that, as the result of the action of some honourable members in recording an important vote last week, the protective policy' of the Commonwealth is in jeopardy. That is the whole burden of the song of the honourable member for Gwydir. He accuses those protectionists whom the Prime Minister has taken into his Cabinet, of being Conservative protectionists. HONORABLEMEMBERS - He a r , hear.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: T h o s e who are acquainted with the political history of the gentlemen who now form part and parcel of the Reid-MCLean Administration, know that they were the Standard bearers of liberalism, progress, and protection throughout Victoria before the honourable member for Gwydir entered public life. The workers of this State-no t the monopolistic manufacturers-hav e to thank the present Treasurer, and the Minister of Trade and Customs, for whatever industrial advantages they enjoy to-dav. " Mr MCDONALD - The honourable member should read the State Hansard reports of MCLean on Turner and Turner on MCLean.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is true that they had their political differences in the State Parliament; but it is well that the people of Australia should be reminded that the only vital point of difference between them was in respect of the method to be adopted is now reto reform the Victorian Constitution. So far as I am aware, it was only in regard to that matter that any difference ever occurred between them as leaders of their respective parties. One believed that the proper method to adopt was to give Parliament an opportunity first of all to make an effort to bring the Constitution up to date; while the honourable member for Gippsland, who was then Premier of Victoria, held that the matter should be dealt with by a Convention, somewhat similar to that which framed the Federal Constitution. I think I am justified in putting these facts before the House, in view of the suggestion on the part of the Opposition that at one time there was considerable rivalry and jealousy between these honourable gentlemen. Both have fought for liberalism and progress, and for the industrial welfare of Victoria, yet the Opposition today hold them up to ridicule as representing the Conservative section of the political life of Victoria. '

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The Conservative section It are supporting the Government today.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: H o n o r a b l e members of the Opposition would have us believe that that is so.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The Argus is supporting them.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: All the Conservative forces are with them.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: B e that as it may, I propose to place a few hard facts before this House.

Speaker: Mr FISHER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable member is protesting too much.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I am not protesting, but I wish to place a few facts before the people, who are the jury that will determine this question. Some reference has been made to the position of the Protectionist Party, and the side on which they ought to sit. But what had the Protectionist Party, to expect from the late Government? What assistance did they receive from honourable members of the Labour Party when the Tariff Bill was before the House? Was there a more bitter opponent of the Protectionist Tariff, as introduced, than was the ex-Minister of External Affairs? He was, if anything, a stronger opponent of the Tariff than was even the presjent Prime Minister. What attitude did the late Government take up when they were questioned on notice as to their intention with regard to the Manufactures Encouragement Bill ? Did they say that they would deal with it as a matter of Government policy? No ; they simply stated that after consideration they were prepared to allow a private member take charge of the Bill , and to afford him an opportunity to submit it to the consideraponent tion of the House.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Will the present vernment take up that Bill ? ,

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: They have not been asked.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable ber should question them on the subject.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I shall make it my business to do so; because it relates to matter to which I am pledged. Not only of the House. the free-trade members of the House, but the Labour Party as a party helped to kill the Bil l as introduced by the Barton vernment.

Speaker: Mr CARPENTER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It was. not made partu question. Mr. KENNEDY - It is absolutely true that the Labour Party, with the late Prime athiests. Minister at their head, and with the assistance of the free-trade section killed the Bill . What had protectionists, who desire to secure bonuses for agricultural and manufacturing purposes, to expect from the late Government?

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The ' honourable member should say something with regard to the Victorian butter bonus.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Le t stand by itself.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is quite strong enough to do so.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is so. I nothing to say in support of the degree of commercial morality

Speaker: Mr MALONEY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Immorality . M.c. KENNEDY - I have nothing to the people of Moira to determine. say in support of the standard of morality which, according to the evidence given bemy fore the Butter Commission, obtains in commercial community. But what has that matter to do with the present political situation ?

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Thos e who are being exposed by the Commission are not members of the Labour Party.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: L a b o u r members not always angels of sweetness and light; they have attained the average

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is a " Kyabramite" who is now being exposed.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That may, or may not be so. Honourable members may Choose to charge me with " KyaDramism," but they seem to forget that at the for any privilege from them. last election I had the pleasure of fighting the Chairman of the Reform League.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: We merely say that the to honourable member is in bad company.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: W it h such an opI may have been in bad company, but circumstances have forced me into the Gocompany in which I now find myself. Much stress has been laid on the allegation that the protectionists are today in bad company, but what had we to hope memfrom the late Government?

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable member admits that there are more protectionists a on this side than on the Government side

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That merely goes to show that there are more protectionists Gogone wrong. What has the industrial life of Victoria ever been able to obtain from a the Labour Party, so far as the protectionist polficy is concerned? The party prides itself on being a body of fiscal An HONORABLEMEMBER - Not the ma of the House, jority of them.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Why is it that they gave no adhesion to fiscal principles when the Tariff Bill was before Parliament?

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: What did the free trade party do for the industrial life of Australia ? that matter Mr KENNEDY - What is the honourable member for Bourke squealing about? He has probably been forced into his proper position- a position which he should have have occupied before. I wish him luck.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: He is sitting where the honourable member should be.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is a matter for The honourable member is not the guardian 'of conscience or of my political principles. our What hope had he of passing the Manufactures Encouragement Bill while the late Government was in office?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: E very hope.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: What was the reply which the honourable member received when are he inquired what course the Government intended to take in regard to that Bill ? He was simply informed that the Government would afford him an opportunity to bring in the Bill before the House. Will he ask the present Government to accord opposite him the same privilege?

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I would not ask So far as I am concerned, it will be a stand-up fight against them.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is immaterial to me on which side of the House I sit; I am not stripped of my political principles from my support of any party. Mr .FRAZER - That reduces the Government majority to one.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It does not so far as the Government programme is concerned

Speaker: Mr FRAZER
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The programme of the Reid-MCLean Administration has not yet been published.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is bound to be a " crawling one."

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: A programme was formulated by the party now in office, and we were told by the late Government that it in no way differed from their own.

Speaker: Mr TUDOR
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That being so, why were .the late Government displaced?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: - That is a question which the honourable member will have to decide for himself. The late Government selected their own battle-ground, and said that if a certain vote were given they would have to leave the Treasury benches. That vote was given, and their lamentations are now being poured forth.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Where ? All we that we had no chance to fairlv deal with the position.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I venture to say that the Opposition will have ample opportunity to reflect.

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I am afraid it will not very long before we shall have to get to work again.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Honourable members may yet see the error of their ways. I am really delighted that the enthusiastic supporters of the Government recently disanother possessed have found their voices so readily. For the last three months I have been some doubt whether they ha'd not pledged themselves to complete silence. that they have found their voices again, it is pleasing to reflect that whenever question comes before us, we shall their opinions freely expressed. that will be found best for all parties. I desire to emphasize the point that these 01 able gentlemen, and more particularly members of the new organization which has been brought into existence by the circumstances by which we have been confronted during the last few days-the members the Liberal Protectionist Association, is going to be the be-all and end-all of industrial life in Australia-thos e honourable members appear to forget that so far tection, as represented on the statute-book, concerned, the electors of Australia, at the last general election, decided what the policy of this Parliament should be. They decided that the Tariff should not be interfered with, except in connection with questions incidental to preferential trade. Now what are honourable members talking about? They are claiming now that the re-opening of the Tariff was the practical business for which protectionists were sent into this Parliament. How utterly absurd that is, and especially coming from such honourable members as the honourable member for Bourke, and the secretary of the Protectionist Association.

Speaker: Mr SPENCE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Surely it is the business of protectionists to see that protection does not disappear?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Is there any danger to protection, so far as it is represented by the Tariff, whilst the honourable member for Gippsland is administering the Customs Department ?

Speaker: Mr SPENCE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Yes ; there is.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I have as much confidence in that honourable gentleman's administration of the Tariff as I have adsay is miration and respect for its administration by the late Minister of Trade and Customs, the honourable member for Wide Bay, by whom the letter, and spirit of the Customs Act was faithfully adhered to.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Does the honourable be member not think that there is some danger when the protectionist party is split into two ?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: B e for e honourable members who complain that the protectionist party is split into two accuse members of partu. they should take a little retrospective view of the situation, and ask in themselves who is to blame for the split? They should not accuse the other fellow of Now all the sins in the Decalogue.

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: Surely those protecany tionists who are now supporting the freehave traders are to blame for the split? I think

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: M i g h t I ask what is hon the fiscal creed of the party whom the hon the orable member is now supporting? They represent no fiscal creed.

Speaker: Mr HUMECOOK
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The majority of the party are protectionists, whilst the majority of of the party which the honourable member which is supporting are free-traders.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: How is the majoritv of the party to be ascertained ? Has the as prohonorable member for Bourke any proof is that the majority of the party, in the tail of which he is the smallest joint, have any fiscal creed of their own ?

Speaker: Mr HUME COOK
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: H as the honourable member any proof that the free-traders will help him?

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is not expected that they will help us.

Speaker: Mr REID
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: They are not traitors.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: That is just whatthey are- a whole set of traitors-and the right honourable, gentleman is the arch-traitor of the lot.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: I have this comforting reflection, that as soon as there is any deviation from the programme laid down, or the policy I am here to support, the honourable gentlemen who constitute the present Cabinet know that they cannot hope for any allegiance of mine. principles will not be wrecked for the support of any party. With that confidence' between us, it does not lie in the mouth of any honourable member, and especially of the honourable member for Gwydir, whose movements have taken him round the political compass, to reproach me. I appreciate the sympathy which honourable members opposite have extended to honourable members on this side, but I may be permitted to say that, so far as I am concerned"] I am not in the least degree uncomfortable. Mr CA RP ENTER - The honourable member ought to be.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: It is not what I ought to be, but what I actually am. ' When I am looking for a leader for my fiscal .creed, it is absolutely useless for me to look to a party who, while proclaiming themselves the party of the industrial workers of Austra lia, are without any fiscal creed whatever.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: When I came in just now I had not the slightest intention of saying a word. I really cannot understand why it is that the honourable member who has just resumed his seat should have spoken with such heat.

Speaker: Mr KENNEDY
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: No heat at all .

Speaker: Mr WATSON
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
text: The honourable member had to justify himself.

Speaker: Sir WILLIAM LYNE
Title: ADDITIONS TO ELECTORAL
